{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3658338,"name":"Luiz Guilherme Forest Gomes ","username":"Forest_gomes","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-19T21:04:32.755Z","cooked":"

We’ve had a lot of problems with the lack of time to program the robot. For example, this season we had less than a week to get everything working. So, my team and I want to invest more in physics-based simulation. During the regional, we managed to simulate our drivetrain using just the WPILib API, which helped us work on our autonomous routines. But now we want to go further — we want to simulate other subsystems of our robot and have full 3D visualization (We plan to use Advantage Scope for the visualization).

I’ve been reading the WPILib docs about physics simulation and mechanism simulation, but I haven’t had much success (I’m not very good at understanding the documentation). So, I’m here to ask for some tips. Does anyone have advice on where to start with mechanism simulation, or do I just need to read through the docs? And regarding Advantage Scope — does anyone have any tips for using it?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-19T21:04:32.755Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":24,"reads":285,"readers_count":284,"score":222.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503394,"topic_slug":"robot-simulation","display_username":"Luiz Guilherme Forest Gomes ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68229,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-simulation/503394/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3658459,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T01:10:28.982Z","cooked":"

I am working on a few things to help solve this very problem and I am looking for beta testers. If you’re interested please join the YAGSL discord and i can share the details there.

I strongly urge you to look into Nstrikes project here. It seems like it will benefit both you and your team!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T01:28:32.875Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":94.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503394,"topic_slug":"robot-simulation","display_username":"Chris","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5561 Prog Lead"},"post_url":"/t/robot-simulation/503394/3","custom_user_title":"5561 Prog Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658633,"name":"Owen Tharp","username":"Grumpy_Bud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/e274bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T13:27:25.568Z","cooked":"

Look at examples from other teams who do similar things, like 6328 (who created advantagescope). I recommend just reading through their simulation and visualization code until it makes sense, and at that point you may be able to replicate it. For me, I read the docs of advantagescope until I fully understood the implementation, and then tried some simple stuff. It’s hard at first and the documentation could be improved, but just some experimentation should get you to that point.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-06-20T13:27:25.568Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":38.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503394,"topic_slug":"robot-simulation","display_username":"Owen Tharp","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68308,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-simulation/503394/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3658720,"name":"Otto","username":"GreenTomato","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greentomato/{size}/214780_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T18:00:40.715Z","cooked":"

This past year was our first year doing pretty thorough simulation and we found a couple things:

  • 3D Simulation isn’t very useful for anything practical, its nice to show off to judges/other teams and its pretty interesting but you don’t really benefit from it outside of looking at mach replay in a cool way (its also a pain to set up, it can take anywhere from 30 minutes to a couple hours)
  • Similar to 3D simulation having a physics sim for gamepieces, robot collision, tipping, etc. isn’t very useful outside of showing other teams/judges
  • Just being able to simulate your state machine or command logic lets you speed up testing so much, we cut down our testing time for “does the mechanism move when i press a button” to like 30 mins per subsystem and were able to focus on autos/auto align much more (thats the main benefit of sim)
  • AdvantageKit-style IO layers are super useful: Template Projects | AdvantageKit. And the best resources for learning sim you’re gona find are probably in the akit/wpilib docs or other team’s code

For starting with a simple mechanism I recommend taking code for a pivot or something from your past years bot and adding in IO layers (either look at another teams code or read the docs, if neither work for you probably ask in the main discord server)

I would like to agree. 3d displays of mechanism 2ds are all you need. I will continue to set up mechanism 3ds because it is an easier way to check logic than just bars and allows game pieces to be shown instead of just a red or green light. However, something like maplesim will often be not worth the time in build season. Maybe it will be cool or useful in the offseason, but it will almost certainly not help improve robot performance on the field.

Maple Sim with Advantage Kit/Scope were clutch for us this summer

Grumpy_Bud:

and allows game pieces to be shown instead of just a red or green light

In AdvantageScope, you can show a 3d pose as a game piece without having to do the full robot CAD approach. A Mechanism2d plus an accurate-ish game piece pose is likely enough to visually validate behavior.

Generally yes but if you are visualizing game pieces you likely are more experienced with doing mechanism 3ds as well.
